frameset.note: Frames file for 'redevelop' based on judicious transformation of 'develop'. Only one example in the corpus anyway.

roleset.name: create

example.name: transitive-1
example.text: UCLA redeveloped a new promoter gene

example.name: but
example.text: John redeveloped a new promoter gene at UCLA

example.name: creation as DO
example.text: Mitsubishi is also pushing ahead with a controversial plan *trace* to redevelop Marunouchi into a business center of high-tech buildings, a project budgeted for 30 years and six trillion yen.
example.arg: a business center of high-tech buildings

example.name: with source
example.text: John redeveloped a strong argument from the footnotes of the paper.
example.arg: from the footnotes of the paper

example.name: with end-result
example.text: John redeveloped the footnotes into a strong argument.

example.name: with benefactive
example.text: Bill Gates redeveloped DOS for Microsoft

roleset.note: these are also -PRPs, but the tag -PRD can be changed to -PRD-PRP during postprocessing

example.name: with secondary predication
example.text: Albert M. Kligman redeveloped Retin-A to combat acne

example.name: with secondary predication
example.text: Albert M. Kligman redeveloped Retin-A for combating acne

roleset.note: The above structure should be used in all cases, even when it feels like the Arg1 and the purpose clause (secondary predicate) are very closely linked and feel like they should be a single argument. Treebank is inconsistent in it treatment of these; sometimes it's split into two nodes, sometimes there's a single node holding both. If we are consistent in dividing these arguments, it's relatively easy for someone else to merge them. The reverse is not true.

example.name: Manner
example.text: John redeveloped the beach through a trust

roleset.note: Plus the usual assortment of TMPs, LOCs (easily confusable with MNRs, nota bene), ADVs, etc.
